# Chapter 320

*What should I do if someone sees me?*

Youngwoo crept toward the apartment's trash area, moving like a man on a combat mission. Every third step, he froze and scanned the parking lot. When headlights swept across the pavement, he dove behind a telephone pole and held his breath.

The trash bags rustled in his grip. His heart hammered against his ribs.

*Thank God I went through basic training.*

Active duty had been hell at the time, crawling through mud under barbed wire, but the skills stuck. He low-crawled the final ten meters to the bins, dumped the bags, and scrambled back to the apartment entrance.

Inside, Youngwoo sagged against the door. "It was good that I served."

The army had been a sacred duty. Not a waste. He'd hated every minute back then, but now? Pride swelled in his chest.

His mother looked up from the garlic pile spread across the living room floor. Her knife paused mid-peel. "Why are you wearing a mask and sunglasses at night?"

"False accusations." Youngwoo waved a hand. "I have to protect myself. Can you have Sehee take out the trash for a while?"

"Are you insane?" She set down the knife. "What false accusation?"

The concern in her eyes made his stomach twist. Youngwoo dropped onto the floor beside her and grabbed a garlic bulb. "Just joking. Let me help."

*Pak! Pa pa pa pat!*

White cloves flew from his fingers. Skin peeled away in perfect strips, the papery shells falling into a neat pile. His hands moved with mechanical precision, each motion fluid and exact.

His mother's jaw dropped. "How are you...?"

*My son has a talent!*

She'd spent thirty years peeling garlic, but Youngwoo's speed made her look like a beginner. Her chest tightened. All these years, she'd worried about her son. He'd struggled in school, shown no particular gifts, nothing that made him special. The guilt had eaten at her, the fear that she'd failed him somehow.

But this. *This.*

Tears pricked her eyes as the garlic pile grew. Youngwoo kept his head down, fingers working, oblivious to the emotion radiating from the woman beside him.

***

Grid materialized in Reidan after dinner.

His boots hit the castle floor, and he immediately turned toward Irene's chambers. Fifty days until the birth. The thought drove him forward like a clockwork mechanism, faithfully ticking through his nightly ritual.

Irene smiled when he entered. "Dear husband, have a good day today."

She pressed her lips to his cheek. The softness, the warmth, it sent electricity down his spine. Better than any legendary item drop.

*Ttiring~*

> [The child in the belly has felt the true love of the couple, increasing all stats by 1.]

Grid's pulse quickened. *Ten days since the last one.* The stat increases came in patterns now, predictable cycles that he'd started tracking.

*Good start.*

He kissed Irene's forehead and headed for the smithy.

"We greet the great sun of Reidan, Duke Grid!"

The young blacksmiths snapped to attention. Khan grinned from his workstation, hammer in hand.

Grid acknowledged them with a nod and closed his eyes. *Concentrate.* The structure of a human hand floated in his mind, every bone, joint, and tendon mapped after three hours of study.

"Item Creation."

> [What item do you want to create?]

*Will it work?* The skill had limits. Accessories were impossible. Certain weapon types refused to materialize. He could only create what fell within a blacksmith's domain.

Grid's throat clicked as he swallowed. "Hands. I want to create hands."

> [...]

Silence. The system notification hung in the air, blank and unresponsive.

*Is it impossible?* Disappointment began to curdle in his gut, but then...

> [It is hands, not gauntlets?]

The question felt different. More organic, more alive than the usual sterile system prompts.

*Something's happening.*

Grid straightened. "That's right! I want to create hands! Hands based on mine!"

> [It is possible if you set the material as pavranium.]

His blood sang. Grid punched the air. "I will set the material as pavranium!"

*Ttiring~*

The cheerful chime echoed through the smithy. Then the notifications cascaded.

> [You have had the same idea as the legendary blacksmith Pagma.]
>
> [The third class quest 'What Pagma couldn't Achieve' has been created.]

---

**[What Pagma couldn't Achieve]**

**Difficulty:** Class Quest

300 years ago, the legendary blacksmith created the strongest mineral called pavranium.

Pavranium is a mineral with transcendent performance, even above the god mineral adamantium. It would never have been completed without the knowledge of Great Magician Braham.

Pagma was inspired. It was his desire to make something that transcended the gods using pavranium. But the quantity was limited, so Pagma had to consider how to use it.

He conceived the God Hand.

Golden hands that could demonstrate dexterity equivalent to a legendary blacksmith. With the God Hands, Pagma believed he could produce items beyond his current reach.

However, he was unable to complete them. Human life was finite, and Pagma was already old.

Now you have reached the same idea. Create and produce the God Hands. Transcend the foundation set by Pagma by achieving what he could not.

**Quest Clear Conditions:** Fully produce hands made of pavranium.

**Quest Clear Reward:** One of the hidden pieces of Pagma's Descendant, 'Sealed Abilities,' will open.

---

*It's as Braham said.*

The timeline made sense now. Pagma existed 300 years ago, dying even then. Yet somehow, he appeared in history 100 years later. Grid's mind spun through possibilities. *Ghost? No. I'll find out during the story quests.*

He shook his head and refocused. The challenge ahead demanded everything.

*I'll do it.*

Confidence burned in his chest. Three hours memorizing hand anatomy. The structure was etched into his brain.

> [Please design the God Hand.]

A blank blueprint materialized. Grid's hand moved across the interface, sketching joints, metacarpals, the delicate machinery of fingers. The Item Creation skill compensated, refining his crude drawings into elegant schematics.

> ['Design: God Hand' has been acquired!]

*God Hand.* Even the name radiated power. Grid grinned and pulled pavranium from his inventory.

The mineral gleamed gold in the furnace light. He positioned it on the anvil and raised the Legendary Blacksmith's Hammer.

*Ttang! Ttang!*

Silence descended. The young blacksmiths stopped moving. Khan set down his tools. The only sound was metal on metal, a rhythmic heartbeat filling the space.

Grid's world narrowed. Pavranium. Anvil. Hammer. Nothing else existed.

*Ttaang—ttang—!*

The hammer became an extension of his arm. His arm became the hammer. Body and tool merged, moving as a single organism. Each strike fell with perfect precision, shaping the gold.

*Ttaaang!*

The pavranium flowed like liquid, reforming into complex structures. Joints materialized. Fingers took shape. The intricate mechanics of a human hand emerged from formless metal.

Khan leaned forward, breath held. The young blacksmiths' eyes went wide.

> [Your extreme concentration has activated the Legendary Blacksmith's Breath.]
>
> [The Legendary Blacksmith's Breath has increased the effectiveness of your production items.]

Grid blinked. Reality crashed back. He lowered the hammer and stared at the anvil.

Golden hands gleamed in the firelight.

***

*There is no possibility I will lose today.*

Piaro drove his hands into the soil, uprooting vegetables with mechanical efficiency. Grid's level exceeded expectations, but levels weren't everything.

*I'm sorry, My Lord.*

Grid grew quickly. Impressively so. But growth took time. Grid hadn't reached the threshold of legend yet.

*There is still a sky between us.*

Skills couldn't transcend that gap overnight. Yesterday's spar replayed in Piaro's mind. The outcome was predictable. He could win today without sustaining injuries.

*Puk! Puk puk puk puk!*

*Pa pa pa pat!*

Vegetables flew from the earth. Piaro's hands moved without pause, a blur of motion that cleared entire rows in seconds.

Chris watched from the edge of the field, eyes wide. The Five Captains stood beside him, equally stunned.

*I want a farmer like that.*

Pedro lay in ruins, trampled by the golem army. The fields were devastated, food production at zero. But with someone like Piaro? Harvests would improve every quarter. Revenue would soar. The population would rally, reconstruction would accelerate exponentially.

Chris sighed. Envy tasted bitter. Grid had collected named NPCs like rare drops, and Piaro was the crown jewel.

Piaro stood and dusted off his hands. "I should end it here today."

Three hours early. Unprecedented.

Chris approached. "Are you going already? What about the sparring?"

"I have something important today." Piaro brushed dirt from his clothes. "After finishing the field work, we will spar at night. Later."

He walked away, soil still clinging to his boots.

"It must be huge if that old man left early." One of the captains frowned. "He's obsessed with farming."

"Maybe something happened with Overgeared?"

The speculation made sense. Piaro rarely abandoned his fields. What crisis could pull him away?

"Follow him."

Chris gestured. They trailed Piaro through Reidan's sparse streets, maintaining distance. Piaro's insight was supernatural, but the low population made tracking simple enough.

"Huh?"

"Grid?"

Piaro stopped outside a large smithy. Grid emerged from the entrance, armed with two greatswords. His expression was grim, focused, the look of a man preparing for war.

*Is there a feud?*

Chris's mind raced. If Piaro and Grid had fallen out, this was his chance. Recruitment opportunity.

"This idiot doesn't understand who he's facing."

The other captains scoffed. Grid couldn't beat Piaro. They'd all fallen to his hand plow. Ten seconds, maximum, before Grid hit the dirt.

*We were beaten. He'll be destroyed.*

The Five Captains had reached third advancement. They knew Grid's capabilities. The outcome was obvious.

Then the spar began.

"What..."

Chris's mouth fell open. The Five Captains stood frozen, disbelief etched across their faces.
